answers.answer: Kalio is correct, you need a fasting test for a definitive answer.  Many things can affect that reading in a non fasting test. Maybe a pint of Ben and Jerrys before the test? Kidding aside, if you are concerned, ask for a fasting glucose test.

Before tx I was diagnosed with diabetes and started insulin. At the time A1C was 13.8 meaning avg blood sugar over 300.  Doc say diabetes can be an effect of HCV.  Went on Tx and continued insulin, better diet, light exercise - generally more healty living.  Was PCR clear at week 12 which also coincided with a bunch of endocrinology-type tests.  By that time (12 wks into Tx)A1C down to 6.3 avg blood sugar 120.  17 Weeks into TX more endo tests A1C fown to 5.8 - and off insulin.Docs believe (and so do I) that for me diabetes was a manisfestation of HCV and that clearing the virus eliminated the diabetes. Just finished TX (last night  - last of the riba) and have a series of post-TX tests schedule over next 3 months to see what happens after body receovers from 'the stuff'.HCV and Tx seem to mask/hide/elevate/worsen other conditions.  Get with your doc - I had no problems with diabetes during tx - just the opposite.
Congratulations on completing treatment. It is a long road and it takes a good deal of internal to get through it.Thanks for your sharing experience, it does help.Bob

My blood sugar had been creeping up for a decade or so.  I started taking Glucophage in 1997,  Its used for type 2 diabetes.  From 2000 to 2002 my weight was down about 50 pounds from cancer tx.  Then I gained some back then started hepc tx in 2002 and lost it again.  The hepc dr said that type 2 diabetes is 3 times as common in hepc patients than in the population,  I didn't ask him why.  While I was on hepc tx my family dr ordered a glycated hemoglobin test.  It's supposed to be the best diabetes test.  I told the hepc dr and he canceled it.  It does a sort of integration over time of your blood sugar but it doesn't work when you're taking riba because the red cells don't last long enough to accumulate sugar on them.  So just measuring plasma sugar is all you can do while on tx.My sugar is on the high side now but not high enough to need a drug.  I'm SVR.Way to go flguy.  You paid the dues and I hope you get the payoff.
